author: @infobae
title: Miles de empleados de Boeing en Estados Unidos iniciaron una huelga general tras rechazar un acuerdo salarial - Infobae
text:
Miles de empleados de Boeing en EEUU iniciaron una huelga general tras rechazar un acuerdo salarial de la empresa REUTERS/David Ryder) Miles de trabajadores de Boeing en Estados Unidos votaron este jueves para iniciar una huelga general y así rechazar un contrato salarial propuesto por la compañía.
La votación mostró que el 94,6 % de los trabajadores rechazó la oferta y el 96 % apoyó ir a huelga, según Jon Holden , presidente del Sindicato Internacional de Maquinistas y Trabajadores Aeroespaciales (IAM, por sus siglas en inglés), Distrito 751 .
“Nuestros miembros hablaron fuerte y claro esta noche”, afirmó Holden, quien representa a unos 33.000 trabajadores en el Pacífico Noroeste . “Nos vamos a huelga a la medianoche”, añadió.
La medida cierra dos plantas principales de ensamblaje de aviones en la región de Puget Sound.
La huelga cerrará dos plantas principales de ensamblaje de aviones en la región de Puget Sound (REUTERS/David Ryder) A pesar del resultado, Boeing expresó su disposición a retomar las negociaciones. “ Seguimos comprometidos a restablecer nuestra relación con nuestros empleados y el sindicato, y estamos listos para volver a la mesa y alcanzar un nuevo acuerdo ”, dijo la empresa en un comunicado.
El nuevo CEO de Boeing, Kelly Ortberg , había propuesto un aumento salarial del 25 % en un período de cuatro años, junto con un compromiso de inversión en la región de Puget Sound, para evitar una huelga.
Ortberg describió este aumento como “el mayor en la historia” y advirtió que una huelga “pondría en peligro nuestra recuperación compartida, erosionando la confianza de nuestros clientes y afectando nuestra capacidad de determinar nuestro futuro juntos”.
La votación mostró que el 94,6 % de los trabajadores rechazó la oferta y el 96 % apoyó ir a huelga, según Jon Holden, presidente del Sindicato Internacional de Maquinistas y Trabajadores Aeroespaciales (IAM, por sus siglas en inglés), Distrito 751 (REUTERS/David Ryder) Sin embargo, los trabajadores rechazaron el acuerdo, que inicialmente había sido respaldado por los líderes del sindicato. Los empleados criticaron que el aumento del 25 % no era tan generoso como se afirmaba, ya que el nuevo contrato eliminaba un bono anual.
Paul Janousek , un electricista de Everett , explicó que su aumento real sería de solo el 9 % después de la eliminación del bono.
“Hablan de un aumento del 25 % y no es así”, dijo Janousek, quien ha trabajado en Boeing durante 13 años.
Otro punto de conflicto fue la negativa de Boeing a restaurar el plan de pensiones y la falta de un compromiso claro de construir su próximo avión en la región de Seattle, lo que los trabajadores consideran una promesa sin garantías más allá del período del contrato de cuatro años.
Los empleados criticaron que el aumento del 25 % no era tan generoso como se afirmaba, ya que el nuevo contrato eliminaba un bono anual (REUTERS/David Ryder) Joe Philbin , un mecánico estructural que lleva seis meses en Boeing, también expresó su apoyo a la huelga. “ Hacer huelga no es lo ideal, pero es lo mejor para tu bienestar a largo plazo ”, afirmó.
Dijo que buscará otros trabajos si la huelga se prolonga, pero que él y su esposa han postergado la decisión de tener hijos hasta que la situación laboral se estabilice. “Boeing es una empresa enorme, pueden permitirse pagar un poco más a las personas que hacen el trabajo”, agregó.
La compañía de aviones expresó su disposición a retomar las negociaciones y afirmó que “seguimos comprometidos a restablecer nuestra relación con nuestros empleados y el sindicato, y estamos listos para volver a la mesa” (REUTERS/David Ryder) El IAM tiene antecedentes de huelgas, con la más reciente en 2008, que duró 57 días.
Holden reconoció que inicialmente apoyó el acuerdo presentado como la mejor opción disponible sin tener que recurrir a una huelga. No obstante, declaró que “el verdadero poder” está en manos de los trabajadores.
En una conferencia de prensa, Holden señaló que las recientes victorias sindicales en otras industrias les habían dado una razón para “aspirar a lograr algo también”.
Richard Aboulafia , director de la consultora AeroDynamic Advisory , señaló que una huelga prolongada podría afectar los planes de recuperación de Boeing, aunque mencionó que una huelga en Spirit AeroSystems , proveedor de Boeing, en 2023 duró menos de dos semanas.
Boeing ha estado bajo escrutinio desde enero, cuando un panel del fuselaje de un Boeing 737 MAX de Alaska Airlines se desprendió en pleno vuelo, lo que obligó a realizar un aterrizaje de emergencia.
Holden indicó que esperaba reanudar pronto las negociaciones. “La votación del jueves envía un mensaje contundente de que nuestros miembros merecen algo mejor”, concluyó.
(Con información de AFP)

author: VNExplorer
title: Melbourne Sikh taxi driver praised after returning $8k cash he found in his cab
text:
Money left strewn across back seat He handed it in to police READ MORE: $90million Lotto winner's 'crazy' error
A Melbourne taxi driver who has driven cabs for more than three decades has been praised for his honesty after returning a large stash of cash found left behind in his vehicle.
Charanjit Singh Atwal recently found a wallet and $8,000 in cash scattered across the backseat of his taxi.
Instead of pocketing the cash for himself, the Sikh driver immediately handed it into police so the rightful owner could be tracked down.
The honest cabbie said it never crossed his mind to keep the money.
Astonishingly, the rightful owner was reunited with his cash.
Mr Singh Atwal did not ask for a reward from the grateful owner.
Charanjit Singh Atwal recently found $8,000 on the backseat of his taxi
‘No, no. I don’t need it. Never, ever,’ the 13cabs driver told Nine News.
He told the Herald Sun: ‘I remember the passenger who lost it was in a hurry; he was very lucky as I had many passengers after him.’
‘Needless to say, he was very grateful.’
Aussies were quick to praise the cab driver after his story was posted online and went viral.
‘A good and honest man. This speaks volumes about his character. May he be blessed abundantly,’ one wrote.
‘He is blessed, and his honesty and good deed will be returned to him tenfold,’ one said.
‘Yup! Great morals, great ethics ! Respect,’ another wrote.
Others were disapppointed to learn that the owner of the cash didn’t give Mr Singh Atwal a reward.
‘No reward? What an a

author: Valley City Times-Record
title: Luna Luz Clothing Launches Innovative Line Of Baby Clothes That Fit Up To 3 Times Longer | User | times-online.com
text: Luna Luz Clothing, a newcomer in the world of baby apparel, is pleased to announce the official launch of its e-commerce platform featuring a line of baby clothing crafted from revolutionary bamboo fabric. This unique material not only provides superior comfort for infants but also boasts an exceptional ability to stretch, ensuring a longer lifespan for each piece. Designed with busy parents in mind, Luna Luz Clothing's bamboo-based baby clothing is poised to redefine the way parents approach dressing their little ones. The innovative fabric allows each piece to stretch and adapt to a growing baby's size, accommodating their rapid development and extending the lifespan of the clothes up to three times longer than traditional fabrics. Given the longer lifespan of their clothing line, parents can now experience the convenience of purchasing fewer items, while still ensuring their babies are comfortably and stylishly dressed. The reduced need for constant replacements not only simplifies the shopping process but also aligns with modern parenting values of sustainability and waste reduction. Beyond the uniquely stretchy clothes, Luna Luz Clothing’s mission is to simplify life for parents. Since traditional baby clothing typically only fits for a few months, an infant’s entire wardrobe usually has to be replaced several times a year. This is one more thing parents have to address when raising their children on top of the numerous other responsibilities they already have. Luna Luz Clothing offers this simple, yet elegant solution of their new clothing line to help parents buy, wash, and store less so that they can spend more time with their children. Visit https://lunaluzclothing.com/ to learn more Media Contact Company Name: Luna Luz Clothing Contact Person: Michelle Bray Email: Send Email Country: United States Website: https://lunaluzclothing.com/

author: T13
title: Alarma meteorológica para regiones Metropolitana y O'Higgins
text: Una alarma meteorológica fue emitida para la Región Metropolitana y la Región de O'Higgins en el contexto del temporal que afecta a varias zonas del país, con lluvias y fuertes vientos. Es ante ese escenario que la Dirección Meteorológica de Chile informó de "viento intenso en zonas de las regiones Metropolitana y O'Higgins". [ Lee También ](/noticia/nacional/aeropuerto-santiago-reanuda-sus-operaciones-tras-suspension-por-temporal-2-8-2024) Aeropuerto de Santiago reanuda sus operaciones tras suspensión por temporal La emisión se produjo a eso de las 1.32 de la madrugada y estará vigente hasta la mañana de este viernes 2 de agosto. En cuanto a las zonas afectadas, se informó que sería: Cordillera de la Costa, Valle y Precordillera en la Región Metropolitana y en el valle en la Región de O'Higgins. Metropolitana - Cordillera Costa: 60-70 y rachas de 80 - Valle: 60-70 y rachas de 90 - Precordillera: 60-70 y rachas 90 O'Higgins - Valle: 50-70 y rachas de 80 Alarma meteorológica: ¿En qué consiste? En el sitio oficial de la Dirección Meteorológica se indica que una alarma consistiría cuando "se pronostican fenómenos meteorológicos con un grado de severidad intensa, con muy alto potencial de generar riesgos materiales y de vida en las personas". "Manténgase informado, cumpla las instrucciones generadas por las autoridades y esté preparado para medidas extraordinarias", agregan. [Síguenos en ](https://news.google.com/publications/CAAiEOgjh55R1O_OHSPw0T00iXYqFAgKIhDoI4eeUdTvzh0j8NE9NIl2)

author: Tyler Pager
title: Biden visits Michigan amid anger in Arab community over Israel-Gaza war - The Washington Post
text: WARREN, Mich. — President Biden made his first campaign visit to Michigan on Thursday, meeting with members of the United Auto Workers union and visiting a Black-owned restaurant while studiously avoiding any interaction with the large Arab American community in this state, which has been outraged over U.S. support for Israel’s war in Gaza. Top Michigan Democrats have pressed Biden for months to spend more time campaigning in their state, but officials have been worried about his visit being overshadowed or interrupted by demonstrators. On Thursday, Biden officials took steps to keep his visit more secretive than usual. They did not publicize the location of his events, and the president’s motorcade avoided protesters by using side streets. But the visit was not entirely free of confrontation. While Biden was holding a political meeting at a local restaurant, a group of protesters chanted “Shame on you,” “Genocide Joe” and “How many kids did you kill today?” The last phrase echoed chants that were aimed at President Lyndon B. Johnson during the Vietnam War. Biden has tightly embraced Israel as it mounts a military campaign against Hamas in Gaza that has killed more than 26,000 Palestinians. Israel’s campaign began after an attack by Hamas on Oct. 7, in which militants surged out of Gaza and killed more than 1,200 people, most of them civilians, and took another 253 hostage. In Michigan, which has one of the nation’s largest Arab American and Muslim populations, with about 300,000 people who claim ancestry from the Middle East or North Africa, the war in Gaza has consumed the community. Many have turned on the president as a result of his unwavering support for Israel and what they see as a lack of empathy for the Palestinians , leaders and residents say. Some Michigan Arabs and Muslims have launched an “Abandon Biden” campaign, part of a broader national effort encouraging members of their community not to vote for Biden. The Biden campaign did not answer questions about why the president did not engage with members of the Arab American or Muslim communities during his visit Thursday. “President Biden met today with some of the 130,0000 UAW Michigan workers who endorsed him last week — and to assure them he’ll continue fighting against Donald Trump’s historically anti-worker agenda that closed factories, shipped jobs overseas, and handed the super-rich tax giveaways,” Lauren Hitt, a spokesperson for Biden’s campaign, said in a statement. “The President’s fight for higher wages and lower costs for middle class families is central to this election.” She added: “Voters can expect to see the President make many trips to Michigan between now and Election Day, and we look forward to reaching voters across the state.” Still, the trip highlighted Biden’s dilemma when it comes to Michigan. It is a swing state critical to his reelection hopes, and he will have to court its voters and make regular visits to capture its electoral votes. But the anger of its Arab community means every visit is likely to be accompanied by protests and demonstrations. Karine Jean-Pierre, the White House press secretary, told reporters Thursday that senior Biden officials will travel to Michigan this month “to hear directly from community leaders on a range of issues that are important to them and their families, including the conflict of Israel and Gaza.” She declined to specify which officials would be traveling to the state or when. Last week, Julie Chavez Rodriguez, Biden’s campaign manager, traveled to Michigan, where she planned to meet with Arab American elected officials and community leaders. But some officials refused to meet with her, citing Biden’s resistance to calling for a cease-fire in Gaza. There are few paths to winning reelection without Michigan’s 15 electoral votes, and Democrats have grown increasingly anxious that the conflict in the Middle East could endanger Biden’s electoral path there. His stance is unpopular not just with Arab Americans, but also with many younger voters and people of color. Even before the conflict, Michigan Democrats were pushing Biden to spend more time in the critical state, with some of them rolling their eyes when the White House announced Biden will make another trip to Pennsylvania, which he has visited far more than any other state in the country outside his home state of Delaware. On Thursday, Biden celebrated his deep support from labor, which he has long courted, often reminiscing about the crucial support unions gave him in his first Senate race in 1972. Since announcing his reelection campaign in April, Biden has received more than a dozen endorsements from unions, with many throwing their support to him earlier in the presidential cycle than usual, including the AFL-CIO, the nation’s largest labor federation. “Wall Street didn’t build the middle class,” Biden said while visiting a UAW union hall where workers were volunteering at a phone bank ahead of the Michigan Democratic primary later this month. “Labor built the middle class. And the middle class built the country.” Biden also held a “kitchen table conversation” with some of the union members about the impact his agenda is having on their lives, his campaign said. “We’re going to fight like hell, and we’re going to ensure Joe Biden is the next president,” UAW President Shawn Fain said. The union formally endorsed Biden last month. Biden’s visit to Michigan was also part of the jockeying between him and former president Donald Trump as each tries to present himself as the better friend to working Americans. Biden took the rare step of joining a UAW picket line last September, and Trump recently met with leaders of the Teamsters union. Biden won Michigan by more than 150,000 votes in 2020, after Donald Trump carried the state by fewer than 11,000 votes in 2016. Democrats and Republicans in the state expect the margin to be close again this year, and to win Michigan, Biden will probably need strong turnout from Black and Arab American voters. Last month, a poll from the Detroit News and WDIV-TV found Biden trailing Trump by eight percentage points in Michigan, and only 17 percent of likely voters said Biden deserved a second term. A New York Times-Siena poll in late October found that 22 percent of Black voters in six battleground states, including Michigan, would support Trump if the general election were held today. Four years ago, Trump won just 8 percent of Black voters nationally. Former Michigan governor James Blanchard (D) said he is confident Biden will win Michigan again, citing his record, the strength of the state Democratic Party’s organization and the UAW’s early endorsement. Blanchard added that he thought Biden was right to not focus on the Arab American community during this trip. “At this point, the issues are so emotional, half of them don’t want to meet with him anyway,” he said, adding: “I just don’t think it’s productive to meet with a screaming crowd. The most important thing is that he’s working to solve the serious challenges in the Middle East. We’re lucky to have him. Imagine what would be going on if it was Donald Trump.” Before meeting with union members, Biden stopped at They Say, a Black-owned restaurant in Harper Woods, where he made the rounds at the bar and tables, smiling for selfies and chatting with patrons. Taylor Harrell was sitting at the bar eating chicken Alfredo when she saw black SUVs pull into the restaurant’s parking lot. She thought it was a sting operation until she was told the president of the United States was visiting. Harrell, 30, voted for Biden in 2020 and plans to do so again in November. “People are looking for something to be wrong, and while there are things that need to be improved, we are not as bad off as we were when Trump was president,” she said. Across the restaurant, Shanelle Gardner, 33, videotaped the president’s every move. A Biden voter, she cited the president’s support for striking autoworkers last fall. Many of her family and friends work for Stellantis, the parent company of Chrysler, she said, and they got raises after the UAW struck a new deal with the automakers, with Biden’s backing. “That was something really big the president had something to do with,” Gardner said. Yasmeen Abutaleb and Emily Guskin in Washington contributed to this report.

author: fashionnetwork.com
title: La marca argentina Violetta Cosméticos recorre el país con su Beauty Movil
text:
La marca argentina Violetta Cosméticos inició 2025 con fuerza, reforzando su presencia tanto en el ámbito local como internacional. En el marco de una gira que está realizando por distintos puntos de Argentina, la compañía visitó la ciudad de Junín, en la provincia de Mendoza, con su Beauty Móvil, el primer salón de belleza itinerante del país.
La marca argentina Violetta Cosméticos recorre el país con su Beauty Movil - Linkedin Violetta
Durante el evento, más de 60 000 personas por día tuvieron la oportunidad de conocer los productos de la marca y disfrutar de sesiones gratuitas de belleza de uñas.
Fundada en 1978, Violetta se especializa en la venta directa de cosméticos, fragancias y productos para el cuidado de la piel, con un enfoque en ingredientes naturales. En sus líneas destacan productos como jabones, lociones, labiales, mascarillas y maquillajes, entre otros.
Su red de revendedoras, presente en provincias como Córdoba, Mendoza, Santa Fe y Salta, es el pilar de su estrategia comercial. Además, la empresa cuenta, desde 2019, con su sitio de e-commerce, permitiéndole ampliar su alcance en todo el territorio argentino y también en el merado regional.
A nivel internacional, Violetta continúa creciendo. En 2017 ingresó al mercado boliviano en alianza con Poscosmética, y en julio de 2024 desembarcó en Guatemala a través de la cadena Republic Cosmetics. Más recientemente, a fines de 2024, la compañía extendió su presencia a Venezuela en colaboración con Grod Importadora.

author: cenutrios_unidos
title: #6 Sánchez celebra la salida de Vox de gobiernos autonómicos: "Es un gran día para España"
text:
Portada
mis comunidades
otras secciones
Al final el gobierno frankenstein, el que iba a reventar por un lado u otro, ahí sigue. Y mientras el PP teniendo que lidiar con una panda de paletos vociferantes como aliados, y ahora además con una escisión aún más paleta y aún más vociferante.
Pues voy a hacer de abogado del diablo. Lo primero de todo es que avisaron de salirse de los gobiernos si se cumplía lo del reparto de menores...y han cumplido. Seguramente si hubieran reculado ya estaríamos con el mantra de los sillones y las poltronas.
Se está celebrando el reparto, cuando seguimos sin atajar el problema. Muchos de ellos no son menores, no tenemos información alguna suya previa y por mucho que digamos donde deberían estar es con sus familias.
Supongo que desde la perspectiva de la "izquierda" esto es una fiesta. Pero no todo el mundo piensa igual y esto es un problema que ni los políticos de izquierda o derecha se van a comer en sus barrios y casas.
Luego vendrán los sesudos análisis del auge de la ultra derecha.
Y bueno, ahora ya podéis tildarme de fascista o lo que os salga de las pelotas por no seguir el ideario estándar de la izquierda.
